metadata.title: The origin of negative stacking fault energies and nano-twin formation in face-centered cubic high entropy alloys

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Scripta Materialia
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate /scr ip tamat
Regular article
The origin of negative stacking fault energies and nano-twin formation in face-centered cubic high entropy alloys
Y.H. Zhang, Y. Zhuang, A. Hu ⁎, J.J. Kai, C.T. Liu Department of Mechanical and Biomedical Engineering, City University of Hong Kong, Kowloon Tong, Hong Kong
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: alicehu@cityu.edu.hk (A. Hu).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.scriptamat.2016.11.014 1359-6462/© 2016 Acta Materialia Inc. Published by Elsev
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 27 September 2016 Received in revised form 8 November 2016 Accepted 14 November 2016 Available online xxxx
The secrets behind the exceptional mechanical properties of high entropy alloys (HEAs) at cryogenic temperatures have drawn much attention in recent years. In this work, the negative stacking fault energy of FCC CrNiCo and FeCrNiCo alloys are disclosed by first-principles calculations. We found that the negative SFEs originate from the thermodynamic metastability of FCC stacking sequence and heavily influenced by the local atomic environment, which in turn affects the formation of stacking faults and nano-twins.
© 2016 Acta Materialia Inc. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Keywords: High entropy alloy Stacking fault energy First-principles Phase stability

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
High entropy alloys (HEAs) have drawn much attention due to the simultaneous improvement of strength, ductility, and toughness at cryogenic temperature [1]. In HEAs, stacking faults and nano-twins are of great research and technology interests, as they contribute to the astonishing improvements of mechanical properties [2,3]. Understanding their formation is significant for conquering the trade-off between strength and toughness in metallic alloys.
A great deal of theoretical studies has focused on the low stacking fault energies (SFEs) in HEAs. The pioneering work of Zaddach et al. [4] predicted the stacking fault energy of two- to five-component alloys using a combination of experimental measurements of microstrain and ab initio calculations of elastic moduli. They concluded that the stacking fault energy would decrease with the number of components increasing. Bhattacharjee et al. proposed that the low SFEs in HEAs were due to the combined effect of the high energy level of the distorted matrix and the relieving of strain energy by in situ adjustment of solute atoms in the stacking faults, but not due to the Suzuki mechanism [5]. Later on, the Suzuki mechanism was emphasized by Patriarca et al. [6]. They studied the role of solute segregation effects on SFE by first-principles calculations and claimed that the presence of Co atoms was favored near the stacking faults, reducing the SFE by almost 55% (from 38 mJ/m2 to 17 mJ/m2) when compared to the presence of Co atoms away from stacking faults.
In the present work, the stacking fault energies in certain FCC (CrNiCo, FeCrNiCo) and HCP (FeCrNiCo) HEAs were calculated using
ier Ltd. All rights reserved.
the first-principles method in combination with the special quasi-random structure (SQS) technique [7,8]. We predicted the SFEs of intrinsic stacking faults for HEA alloys with FCC or HCP structures at 0 K. Furthermore, we found that the local atomic environment would influence heavily on the SFEs. The thermodynamic results indicate the formation of intrinsic stacking faults in FCC HEAs could be a spontaneous process at low temperatures if no significant kinetic barrier. A positive energy input is not necessarily required when introducing defective structures inHEAs, especially intrinsic stacking faults in FCCHEAs.Moreover, those defective structures are intrinsically stable in HEAs. These results would help in the design of novel HEA alloys with low SFEs and excellent mechanical properties.

sections.heading: 2. Methodology
sections.text:
Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed by usingVienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [9,10]with the projector augmented wave (PAW) method [11,12]. The exchange-correlation functional was chosen as the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) parameterized by Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) [13]. The semicore p states of all elements were treated as valence electrons, and plane-wave energy cutoff of 600 eV and Monkhorst–Pack [14] kpoint spacing of 0.2 Å−1 were used for all calculations. The energy and the force tolerance were 1.0 × 10−7 eV and 1.0 × 10−3 eV·Å−1, respectively. To determine the equilibrium lattice constants, the geometry optimizationwasdoneusing SQS supercellswith 108 and 96 atoms for FCC and HCP structures, respectively. Simulation of random HEA alloys using SQSmethod, allows the atomic relaxation to reproduce the severe lattice distortion in HEAs.
Our calculations were mainly performed on non-magnetic structures (i.e., non-spin-polarized). The theoretical calculation of Ma et al. [15] suggested that HEAs have almost vanishing local magnetic moments at equilibrium volume and closely resemble to the non-magnetic state. Experimentally, para-magnetism was identified for FeCrNiCo and CrNiCo. In all, it's safe to treat HEAs as non-magnetism here.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
In Table 1, the lattice parameters are tabulated for CrNiCo and FeCrNiCowith FCC and/orHCP structures, togetherwith the comparison of other theoretical work and experimental measurements. The lattice constants of FCC CrNiCo and FeCrNiCo are predicted to be 3.515 Å and 3.498 Å, respectively. They agree very well with other theoretical studies (3.516 Å for CrNiCo [16] and 3.51 Å for FeCrNiCo [17]), and experimental results (3.579 Å for CrNiCo [18] and 3.575 Å for FeCrNiCo [4]). Besides, the lattice constant of CrNiCo alloy is 0.5% smaller than that of the quaternary FeCrNiCo alloy. Experimental results also show the same trend, which verifies the reliability of our calculations. For HEA alloys with HCP structure, no structural information is available in experiments. The lattice constants of HCP FeCrNiCo arefirstly reported here as 2.491 Å (a) and 3.981 Å (c). For HCP CrNiCo, the lattice constants are predicted to be 2.492 Å (a) and 4.031 Å (c), which also agree very well with the calculation results of Zhang et al. (2.499 Å (a) and 4.013 Å (c)) [16].
Thereafter, we constructed the intrinsic stacking faults for FCC CrNiCo and FeCrNiCo, as well as HCP FeCrNiCo based on the optimized structural parameters. First, the pristine supercells with 192 atoms were built upwith a bulk slab and a vacuum slab of 16 Å. The lattice vectors of the supercells were defined asa= [2 02]fcc,b= [0 22]fcc, c= [4 4 4]fcc for the FCC structures, anda= [4 0 0 0]hcp, b= [0 4 0 0]hcp, c= [0 0 0 6]hcp for the HCP phases. The vacuum slab was added to screen the pseudo-interactions between periodically repeated slabs. To create the stacking faults, the upper half part of the supercells were rigidly sheared along the Shockley partial dislocations, i.e., bp=1/6[112]a0 in FCC struc-
tures andbp=1/3[1010]a0 in HCP structures (where a0 is the lattice constant). Thereafter, the origin c vector was distorted as c0 ¼ ðcþ bp). Finally, a relaxation scheme of pure alias shear (a full relaxation of the supercell and atomic coordinates with the only constraint of shearing angle fixed) [6,19,20] was utilized for the faulted supercells. The stacking fault energy was then derived as
γisf= (Eisf− E0) / S0,where Eisf and E0 are the total energies of faulted and pristine supercells, respectively, and S0 is the area of the stacking fault. The corresponding configurations of intrinsic stacking faults (ISFs) are illustrated in Fig. 1. Following the notation by Liu [21], the change of the stacking sequence in FCC materials can be expressed as
…cccccccccccc… → …ccccchhccccc…
and while, in HCP structures, the local atomic stacking change can be expressed as
…hhhhhhhhhhhh… → …hhhhhcchhhhh…
The stacking fault energies for different configurations are summarized in Table 2.
Interestingly, the stacking fault energies in FCC phases are extremely negative at 0 K and spread in a wide range when the local atomic environments are different. In FCC CrNiCo, the ISF configurations of FCC1, FCC2, and FCC3 have negative SFEs at −18 mJ/m2, −49 mJ/m2, and −77 mJ/m2, respectively. The SFEs decrease with decreasing valence electron counts (VECs) and d-electron density near ISFs. Surprisingly, the SFEs change more than three times depending on the local
.
atomic environment around ISFs. The average SFE in FCC CrNiCo is −48 mJ/m2, which reasonably agrees with the result of Zhang et al. (−24 mJ/m2) [16]. Similarly, for FCC FeCrNiCo, the SFEs falls from−82mJ/m2 to−180mJ/m2. If replacing all atoms in FCC3 configuration of FeCrNiCo (a= 3.498 Å) to be Co atoms with largest VEC and d-electron density here, the SFE decreases to−198mJ/m2, which is the most negative value of SFE here. By contrast, most HCP structures have positive stacking fault energies at 0 K. The SFEs of HCP FeCrNiCo change from−8 to+142mJ/m2with the decreasing of d-electron density. The negative SFEs in FCC HEAs and positive SFEs in HCP HEAswill be further discussed later on.
However, the SFE is not solely dependent on the valence electron counts (VECs) and d-electron density. When the VECs (d-electron density) of FCC1 and FCC2 configurations of FeCrNiCo decrease from 8.31 (6.56) to 8.25 (6.50), the SFE increase from −117 to −82 mJ/m2, not following previous trend in FCC CrNiCo and HCP FeCrNiCo. For the FCC Co structure with a lattice constant of 3.547 Å, the SFE is predicted as −0.94 mJ/m2 [22]. The change of SFEs from −198 to −0.94 mJ/m2 when lattice constants or volumes increase indicates the strong temperature dependence of SFEs. Besides, in the non-distorted configurations, the SFEs of FCC3 (HCP3) configuration are predicted as −164 (+256) mJ/m2. After considering lattice distortion effects, it drops to −180 (+142) mJ/m2. With local lattice distortion, the internal stress induced by atomic mismatch in HEAs is released by in situ atomic position adjustment, which makes the alloys structure more stable. Therefore, it boils down to that, the SFEs are heavily influenced by the local atomic environment (or element segregation) as well as the temperature. The local environments would also affect the local lattice distortion, which regulate the SFES again.
The negative (positive) SFEs in FCC (HCP) configurations suggest that the HCP (FCC) stacking would benefit (harm) the structural stability. In other words, the HCP phase is energetically more favorable, and the FCC phase ismetastable at low temperatures. The cohesive energies, as shown in Fig. 2, also verified this argument. In stacking fault-free structures, the system energy of pristine (distorted) FeCrNiCo with HCP3 structure is 22.7 (16.1) meV/atom lower than the FCC1 structure. After introducing ISFs, the system energy of FCC1 structure decreases, while that of HCP3 structure increases. In other words, the defective layers of hexagonal stacking helps the FCC structure becoming more stable, while the defective layers of cubic stacking destabilize the HCP structure. In addition, with ISFs in non-distorted (distorted) HCP3 and FCC1 structures, their energy difference decreases to 12.2 (8.9) meV/ atom. Therefore, compared with the defect-free HEAs, the thermodynamic fluctuation dampen in defective FCC and HCP structures. The thermodynamic preference of HCP stacking at low temperatures is also true for other HEAs, confirmed by the theoretical investigation of
FeCrNiCoMn [15]. In all, the FCC HEAs aremetastable and has a negative SFE at low temperatures. The formation of HCP stacking in FCC structure is energetically favorable and releases system energy. The defective structures with ISFs move to a lower, more thermodynamically stable state. If no kinetic barrier, the formation of ISFs in FCC phases would be a spontaneous process.
It is important to point out that all of these are consistent with the experimental phenomenon at cryogenic temperature. Experimentally, the HEA alloys of FeCrNiCo and CrNiCo are fabricated with FCC structures at elevated temperatures, as FCCphases are thermodynamic stable at high temperatures [15]. To realize the structural transformation of FCC→ HCP, a thermal activation or externally applied stress is required to overcome the transformation barrier. Therefore, the FCC structures keep metastable over an extended temperature range, which ensures the formation of extensive stacking faults and nano-twins at low temperatures.
Surely, the physical origin of negative SFEs in FCC HEAs could be correlated with the electronic structure. The electron localization function (ELF) describes the probability of finding two electrons within a given space. As shown in Fig. 3, the atomsnear the stacking fault are highlighted by black dashed lines. At the corner of these dashed lines, obvious merge of ELF basin (interstitial densitymaxima) shows up in the faulted structures. However, they're obviously separated (marked by arrows in Fig.3) in the ISF-free structures. This reflects the extension of electron clouds among the locally HCP stacking in FCC structures, which benefits the stability of defective structures in FCC HEAs.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In this work, the stacking fault energies (SFEs) in FCC and HCP high entropy alloys (HEAs)were calculated using the first-principlesmethod in combination with the special quasi-random structure (SQS) technique, to disclose the formation mechanism of stacking faults and nano-twins. We found that the negative SFEs originate from the energetic preference of HCP stacking and the metastability of FCC structures at low temperatures. Moreover, SFEs could be effectively tuned by the local atomic environment and the temperature. Meanwhile, the severe lattice distortion would show its contribution, too. These results shed lights on the understanding of the exceptional mechanical properties of HEAs at cryogenic temperatures.
